III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures
Section An agency shall have and follow written policies and procedures
Description for all areas of foster care services as provided in R 400.12203 to
R 400.12214
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not follow their policies regarding notifying parents
of medical appointments and holding family teams meetings.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Phone interviews were scheduled with Parent A, who is also the
complainant, through email exchanges. Calls were made at the
agreed upon time, but she did not answer on 10/6/2023 or
10/10/2023. Parent A did return the missed call on 10/10/2023
and left a voicemail stating she was available the remainder of the
day. A return call was made within 30 minutes, but she did not
answer. On 10/11/2023 Parent A sent an email requesting
interview availability for that day which was provided to her along
with a request for her to call when she was available. She has not
responded.
The only available information from the complainant is what she
wrote in her online compliant which stated the following:
We are never informed of doctors or dentist appointment,
so we have been unable to attend. The few times we have
been notified of the appointment we are told the day before
or the day of, or we are given a day but no time of the
appointment.
We have had literally only 1 family team meeting the entire
duration of the children in care and I had to request it
multiple times.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported she supervised Foster Care Worker 1
2

who was assigned the case from 10/27/2021 until 12/16/2021 and
Foster Care Worker 2 who was assigned to the case 12/16/2021
until 5/27/2022, neither of which are currently employed by the
agency. Supervisor 1 reported during the time she was the
supervisor assigned to the case, the parents had retained an
attorney and insisted that all communication from the agency go
through the attorney. Supervisor 1 stated there was a Family
Team Meeting (FTM) held in March of 2022 at the attorney’s
office, during which the parents were notified of multiple upcoming
medical appointments for the children, particularly Youth B who
had specialist appointments.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. He reported supervising Foster Care Worker 3 who
was assigned the case from 5/27/2022 until 9/30/2022 and who is
no longer employed by the agency. Supervisor 2 reported that
social work contacts in the case record document that Foster Care
Worker 3 notified parents of medical appointments while he was
assigned to the case. Supervisor 2 reported Foster Care Worker 3
held an FTM with the family during which service planning was
discussed.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported supervising Foster Care Worker 4 who
was assigned the case from 9/30/2022 until 6/23/2023 and Foster
Care Worker 5, who was assigned the case 6/23/2023 and is
currently assigned to the case. Supervisor 3 reported that the
case record contains multiple social work contacts documenting
the workers’ attempts to notify the parents of medical
appointment. She stated contact with the parents is difficult
because they will only respond to text or email and will often only
respond to a portion of what was addressed in emails.
Supervisor 3 reported Foster Care Worker 4 attempted to
coordinate an endocrinologist appointment for Youth B with the
parents, but this was difficult due to the foster parents needing to
be in attendance as well, and the foster parents have a PPO
against the parents. Supervisor 3 reported the parents did attend
a well-child appointment for Youth B in July of this year.
Supervisor 3 stated the parents did not attend a medical
appointment for Youth D and Youth E, despite being notified. She
stated the parents are primarily concerned with Youth B’s medical
appointments.
Supervisor 3 reported Parent A and Parent B have attended 3-4
FTMs that she is aware of and have been invited to others they
3

did not attend. She stated the current worker had difficulty
scheduling meeting with the parents due to their lack of response,
at times. Supervisor 3 stated Foster Care Worker 5 recently
scheduled a Team Decision Making meeting, which is the
equivalent of an FTM, with a neutral facilitator. Foster Care
Worker 5 sent reminders to the parents before the meeting, but
neither parent showed up to the meeting and did not let the worker
know until after the meeting they couldn’t attend. Supervisor 3
reported the parents have stated they have lost and broken
phones during the case, which has prevented them from
connecting to virtual meetings. The agency has provided them
with a phone and data plan to ensure they do not have access
barriers; however, they continue to not attend.
Foster Care Worker 4 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported she notified the parents of a 7/10/2023
medical appointment for Youth B. She stated she also notified
them of a medical appointment for Youth D and Youth E but
acknowledged this notification did occur the same day as the
appointment as there was confusion with the foster parents about
the appointment date. Foster Care Worker 4 stated she couldn’t
recall if there were medical appointments for Youth A and Youth C
while they were assigned the case. She added the parents would
ask frequently about Youth B’s medical appointments but did not
ask about the other youth. Foster Care Worker 4 stated she
notified the parents of medical appointments by phone or by text.
Foster Care Worker 5 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported she was assigned the case on 6/26/2023
and is currently assigned to the case. She stated the children
have had several medical appointments since she has been
assigned to the case and she has notified the parents of every
appointment either by phone or text, but she rarely gets a
response. She stated Parent B did attend an endocrinologist
appointment for Youth B which Foster Care Worker 4 also
attended.
Foster Care Worker 5 reported she attempted to schedule a TDM
with the parents and sent an email to Parent A with the meeting
details. Parent A indicated there was a barrier accessing the
virtual meeting, so the facilitator attempted to call Parent A at her
phone number as well as her mother’s number but did not get a
response.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
4

• The agency’s foster care procedure regarding health
services which states parental inclusion in all child’s health
care appointments is to be encouraged and supported and
caseworkers are to notify parents of all health care
appointments.
• The agency’s policy regarding FTMs/TDMs which states all
members of the treatment team are invited to the FTMs.
• Email from Supervisor 3 to Parent A on 5/3/2023 with
7/10/2023 medical appointment date time and location.
• Notes from endocrinologist appointment for Youth B in July
2023 documenting Parent B’s attendance.
• FTM documentation from 3/9/2023 and 4/19/2023 during
which upcoming medical appointments were discussed.
Both parents signed the FTM paperwork verifying their
attendance and participation.
• Social work contacts documenting that the parents were
notified of upcoming medical appointments on 1/25/22,
3/1/2022, 4/11/2022, 6/14/2023, 7/14/2023 and 10/31/2023.
• 16 FTMs documented to have been held, 4 of which Parent
A attended and 2 of which Parent B attended. The parents
signed the FTM documentation verifying their attendance
and participation in these meetings. Social work contacts
were located for every FTM documenting the parents were
invited.
Analysis The agency staff followed agency procedures by notifying the
parents of medical appointments and inviting parents to FTMs.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of Service Plans
Section (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
Description and parent, or parents as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not complete all required service plans.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Phone interviews were scheduled with Parent A; however, she
did not answer at any of the times scheduled.
The only available information is what she wrote in her initial
online compliant which stated:
5

I received the case service plans for every reporting period
for the first time. There was not a Parent Agency Treatment
Report from the whole duration of June 2022 to September
2022, when Foster Care Worker 3 was our caseworker, nor
was there a single document from when Foster Care orker
2 was our caseworker from January 2022 to June 2022.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported what she believes Parent A is
referencing in this complaint is that when she requested copies of
all of her service plans from the agency, the person who provided
the copies missed one PATP and one service plan and PATP.
Parent A contacted the agency about this, and those reports were
sent to her.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
• The electronic case record was reviewed which contains an
initial service plan and 5 updated service plans which are
all of the required service plans.
Analysis The agency staff completed all of the required service plans.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
Section (5) An agency shall involve the parent or parents and the foster
Description parents in the development of service plans to enable the parent
or parents and the foster parents to understand the plan for the
child and the parents’ and foster parent’s role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to
and review the parent agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parents that the information in the parent
agency treatment plan and any other information about the child
and the child’s family is confidential.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not involve parents in service plan development and
did not review the completed service plans with the parents.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Phone interviews were scheduled with Parent A; however, she
did not answer at any of the times scheduled.
The only available information is what she wrote in her initial
online complaint which stated the following:
6

We have never been included in the development of our
case services plan nor has a parent agency treatment plan
been gone over with us. We have never received an initial
case service plan, nor the first updated case service plan.
Every service they claim they have offered has not
occurred other than substance abuse and drug screens.
We started requesting family therapy when we started to
see what this has been doing to our family and we finally
were given information on how to start those services within
the past 2 months. The same with Parent B’s anger
management. We all are aware that Parent B has a little
temper problem. It’s not as if he just lashes out, no, he is
just unable to express himself professionally or in a
productive manner when he’s upset. He doesn’t damage
things or threaten harm in any way. However, we felt it may
be a barrier, so we inquired about anger management
services in April of 2022, yet he was just given the
information for this service in August of 2023. We are not
offered parenting skill classes or anything of that nature.
However, reports state we need to acknowledge our
harmful ways of parenting we have previously displayed
and how it effects our children. In reality, the agency’s
caseworker needs to acknowledge the actions they have
displayed and the effects it is having on my children.
Rather, we are made out to look dangerous and crazy by
the caseworkers and supervisors at the agency.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported the case service plan and parent agency
treatment plan were reviewed with the parents during an FTM that
occurred at the parents’ attorney’s office at which time the parents
stated they wanted to write their own treatment plan. Supervisor 1
stated both parents were referred to BRISA which is a program in
which the parents and children receive trauma assessments from
which a tailored, trauma-informed plan of treatment is developed.
Supervisor 1 stated that the parents would have received parent
education and substance abuse treatment through the program.
Supervisor 1 stated that she knows the trauma assessments were
completed, but the case was transferred to a different supervisor,
so she doesn’t know if the parents followed through on the
services. Supervisor 1 reported Parent A was also referred for a
substance abuse assessment during an FTM at her attorney’s
office after Youth D and Youth E were born with
Methamphetamine in their system. During that FTM, Parent A
agreed to the assessment.
7

Supervisor 2 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023.He reported Foster Care Worker 3 held an FTM with
the parents during which he discussed the case service plan and
reviewed the PATP. Supervisor 2 stated the parents had not yet
been adjudicated at the time he supervised the case; so,
participation in services was not required; however, they were
referred to substance abuse treatment and parenting skills
classes. Foster Care Worker 3 also attempted to complete drug
tests with the parents, but they refused to participate in the testing
or services.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. Supervisor 3 reported Foster Care Worker 4 met with
the parents at least twice and attempted to go over the service
plan and PATP. Supervisor 3 attended a meeting along with
Foster Care Worker 4 attempting to discuss service plan
development; however, the parents did not engage in the
discussion, rather they focused on their belief that the children
should never have been removed and their belief that the court is
not acting properly.
Supervisor 3 stated the parents push back on any services to
which they are referred. Both parents were referred for
psychological testing to occur on 3/13/2023 but they refused to
attend. The parents state they will not participate in services until
someone provides proof that they did anything to facilitate the
removal of their children. Initially, they stated they wouldn’t
participate in services until they were adjudicated but continued to
refuse services after adjudication on 5/9/2023. Supervisor 3 stated
that the one service the parents have requested is family therapy;
however, they will not engage in individual therapy which is
needed to address the trauma both they and the children have
endured prior to engaging in family therapy. Supervisor 3 stated
Parent B did ask about anger management services in April or
May of this year. Foster Care Worker 4 identified a service for him
and offered to make the call to set up the service with him, but it
wasn’t until after the next court hearing in September of 2023 that
he agreed to the service.
Foster Care Worker 4 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported during her first meeting with the parents
after being assigned the case she planned to discuss service
planning; however, the parents had 5 binders of information they
went through regarding their rights, the legal process, and reasons
why they believed the children shouldn’t be in foster care. Foster
8

Care Worker 4 scheduled another meeting with them since they
did not get to the service plan discussion. She went over their
PATP with them, which they refused to sign, stating they wanted
to create their own treatment plan.
Foster Care Worker 4 reported she referred Parent B to the
Disability Network and offered to make the call with Parent B, but
he said he would make the call on his own. Foster Care Worker 4
does not know if he followed through. She stated Parent B initially
stated he would not engage in anger management services to
which he was referred, but later said he would. Parent A was
asking Foster Care Worker 4 about family therapy, but a referral
was not made as Parent A refused to first engage in individual
therapy. Foster Care Worker reported she attempted multiple drug
screens for both parents, which they refused.
Foster Care Worker 5 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported she was assigned the case on 6/26/2023
and is currently assigned to the case. She reported she scheduled
a meeting with the parents to go over their service plan and PATP.
She stated she went through the PATP line by line with Parent B
and he wanted a lot removed from the report. She stated Parent A
was not present for the meeting so Foster Care Worker 5 made an
appointment with her for the following week, but while she was on
her way to the home, Parent B called and cancelled.
Foster Care Worker 5 reported when she did have a face-to-face
meeting with Parent A to discuss service referrals, but the majority
of the visit was Parent A wanting to review policy and Foster Care
Worker 5 had to continually circle back to discussion of services.
Parent A stated someone needs to prove she has a substance
abuse problem before she will engage in services. Foster Care
Worker 5 stated Parent B did not attend that meeting because he
was afraid of becoming escalated.
Foster Care Worker 5 stated she provided Parent A a referral to
individual counseling, but Parent A stated she did not want to use
that service as it was affiliated with the foster care agency, so she
would find someone on her own. Foster Care Worker 5 stated she
hasn’t heard anything from Parent A about this in the past few
months. Foster Care Worker 5 stated she made a call with Parent
B to start anger management services, but when he went to start
the service, the service provider reported there was an issue with
payment. Foster Care Worker 5 states she made the full payment
for the 12-week course yesterday and Parent B was to start the
service tomorrow.
9

Foster Care Worker 5 reported if the parents had engaged in
BRISA, they would have received all-inclusive services. She
stated since adjudication, the parents only want to talk about the
illegal removal of their children, rather than what they need to do
toward getting them back in their home. She stated there was
recently a foster care review board meeting and when Parent A
was given the opportunity to speak, she began talking about the
illegal removal. When someone form the board redirected her and
asked her to talk about services, Parent A dropped off the call.
She later reported she had dropped her phone in a pond.
Foster Care Worker 5 reported the parents recently agreed to
work with Early On for parenting skills. The frequency of those
meetings with be up to the parents. Foster Care Worker 5 stated
there are concerns because they deny Youth D’s developmental
issues resulting from methamphetamine exposure.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
• Six service plans were reviewed in the case records, which
documented the services were referred as described during
the Supervisor and Foster Care Worker interviews.
• Six PATPs were reviewed, one of which was the Initial
Service Plan the complainant alleged she never received,
which was signed by both parents (11/5/2021) and one of
which was signed by Parent B only (5/31/2023.) The
remaining PATPs were documented to have been provided
to the parents either in person or by mail and the parents
refused to sign them.
• 16 FTMs documented to have been held during which all of
the services the workers and supervisors mentioned during
their interviews (including parenting skills, substance
abuse, psychological testing, anger management, and
individual counseling) and case service planning was
discussed, 4 of which Parent A attended and 2 of which
Parent B attended. The parents signed the FTM
documentation verifying their attendance and participation
in these meetings.
• Case contacts documented that at least monthly face to
face service discussions as well as multiple text
message/phone/email discussions were held during which
service referrals were made service plan discussion was
attempted, and/or an update on service participation was
requested.
10

Analysis The agency staff discussed service planning with the parents on
multiple occasions, provided multiple referrals to services, and
provided the parents with the service plans.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12315 Communication
Section An agency’s communication policy must ensure that a child is able
Description to communicate with family and friends in a manner consistent
with the child’s expressed wished, appropriate to the child’s
functioning and in accordance with the child’s treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency has not facilitated any contact between the youth and their
relatives.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Phone interviews were scheduled with Parent A; however, she
did not answer at any of the times scheduled.
The only available information is what was written in the initial
online complain which states:
No Family members have gotten to see the children this
entire duration in care. When we inquire with caseworkers
at the agency, they tip toe around the subject until its
forgotten until we mention it again.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported while she was assigned as supervisor on
the case, there were no requests made by relatives to have
contact with the children nor have the parents requested or
discussed having family members attend parenting time.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
• Social Work contact dated 12/3/2021 documenting a
conversation with Parent A regarding a call received from
Parent B’s grandmother requesting visits with the youths.
Parent A stated she did not want Parent B’s grandmother to
have contact with the children.
• 2/25/2022 text from Parent A stating she has no family
members in Michigan other than her mother with whom she
lives.
• Case contacts with Parent A were reviewed, including text
messages and emails from Parent A, none of which
11

included a request for any family members to visit the
youths.
Analysis The agency followed Parent A’s wishes regarding the one relative
who reached out wanting contact with the youths. The parents did
not identify any other relatives.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
Section (3) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between parents
Description and children except where parental rights have been terminated or
when there is a court determination that visits are detrimental to
the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency has not been consistent in facilitating in-person contact
between parents and children.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Phone interviews were scheduled with Parent A; however, she
did not answer at any of the times scheduled.
The only available information is what she wrote in her initial
online complaint which stated the following:
We had 3 visits in the comfort of the home at the children’s
residence of, to suddenly have them removed from the
home and were conducted in the agency. We have not
been told why this happened nor was there an order on the
matter. Parent B had been refused to see his children by
the agency’s caseworkers for 6 months; telling him he
needed to sign an affidavit of parentage before he was
allowed to see his children regardless the damage done on
either Parent B or the children. Signing the affidavit took
longer than expected however it was done for all 3 children
April 5, 2022, which Foster Care Worker 3 was aware of.
We informed her and provided her with copies. We had a
visit on this day, and it is reported in the parenting time
report about Parent B attending the first visit since October
and about him signing the affidavit that day.
Foster Care Worker 3 told us he was forced by Supervisor
2 to sign a motion that he didn’t write. It was a motion to
suspend parenting time filed August 16, 2022. The court
then adjourned this hearing just as they have the entire
duration of the case, they adjourn EVERY hearing,
however they still suspended our parenting time to the
12

children without any information or proof to suspend it. The
reason they adjourned it to begin with was to gain more
information in regard to suspending parenting time. So how
do they suspend parenting time anyway? However, referee
did state for there to be some kind of virtual parenting time
in the meantime to replace in person. I begged and pleaded
with caseworkers to let me speak to my children.
Our next caseworker, Foster Care Worker 5, didn’t contact
us until October 14, 2021. I asked her so many times for
any kind of contact; that we would be happy with a phone
call. I asked about talking to them on holidays, as this
duration of parenting time being suspended was of course
holiday season of November and December. The motion
was withdrawn January 3, 2023. Parenting time was
basically suspended for that time with no basis or
reasoning behind it only for the motion to be withdrawn
randomly as well. A visit was set up for us and the children
on January 3, 2023, however Parent B and I had difficulties
making it there on the day short notice. Our vehicle was not
legal as well and we had a difficult time getting around at
this time. We were not offered any transportation
assistance and we were unable to make this visit.
Afterward I attempted multiple times a week to set up a
different day for a visit or to have a virtual. I also begged
and inquired on why the visit couldn’t be conducted at our
home. This was when I started to contact supervisors of the
agency. They finally set up a visit for all of us March 15,
2023. They would make us conduct our visits in their
meeting room due to the size of the group. 5 children, their
father and me, and the agency had 2 workers in the room
with us supervising.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported when she was the supervisor on the
case, visits were occurring at Parent A’s mother’s home which is
where Parent A and Parent B live. Supervisor 1 stated that she
made the decision to move the visits to the agency office on
3/9/2022 after safety concerns for the children and the agency
staff supervising the visits arose. Supervisor 1 stated that there
were holes in the walls of the home in which birds would fly in and
out, the family refused to wear masks or use hand sanitizer at the
agency request and would have other people show up to the visits
who would become argumentative with the agency staff during the
visits.
13

Supervisor 1 stated that Parent B had asked for parenting time,
but the court denied the request because he was not established
as the legal father of the children. After some time, he established
paternity of Youth D and Youth E and at a later date did the same
for Youth B and Youth C. He also signed an affidavit of parentage
for Youth B, which caused some confusion at the court as Youth B
has a different legal father, resulting in additional time for the court
to sort out the confusion. After Parent B was established as the
father of Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E, parental visits
were ordered and subsequently scheduled.
Supervisor 2 reported Parent A and Parent B abducted Youth A
and Youth C from their foster home on 8/4/2022. They were
located by law enforcement the following day and returned to the
foster parents. Parent A was arrested and charged with felony
kidnapping and Parent B was released. Foster Care Worker 3
submitted a motion to the court requesting suspension of
parenting time following the kidnapping, which was granted.
Supervisor 2 reported Youth A and Youth C’s foster parents
obtained a personal protection order against Parent A and Parent
B as did the foster parents of Youth B, Youth D, and Youth E;
however, Parent A showed up again at Youth A and Youth C’s
foster home. Supervisor 2 stated that parental visitation was still
suspended by the court at the time the case transferred from
Supervisor 2 to Supervisor 3.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported when she was assigned as the
supervisor on the case, parenting time had already been
suspended due to the parents kidnapping Youth A and Youth C.
She reported that the order did not allow for phone calls or virtual
parenting time either. She stated Foster Care Worker 4 did send
photos of the children to the parents during the holidays. She
reported the court reinstated parenting time 12/27/2023. Parenting
time was scheduled for 1/3/2023 but the parents did not show up,
stating they had transportation issues. Supervisor 3 stated the
parents did not ask for transportation on the day, but the agency
has provided them with gas cards and offered to pay for their van
to be repaired. Supervisor 3 stated neither parent attended
scheduled parenting times between January and March of 2023.
She stated Youth A and Youth C are transported 45 minutes to
attend parenting time, so the court ordered the parents are
required to confirm their attendance and arrive early for their
parenting time to ensure the children aren’t traveling to and from
the agency if the visit isn’t going to occur. Supervisor 3 stated that
the early arrival time did change as the agency was initially
14

requiring the parents to arrive 2 hours early but realized that was
excessive and, in an order, to work with the parents, they reduced
the early arrival. The court reduced the time they had to arrive
even further down to 30 minutes. Supervisor 3 stated there have
been times the parents will call saying they will not make it in time
for their early arrival for various reasons. When asked for an
estimated time of arrival, they stop communicating, so a decision
is eventually made to cancel the visit. Supervisor 3 stated in these
cases the parents do not typically show up, but this scenario did
occur recently, and the parents showed up after the visit was
cancelled. Supervisor 3 reported Foster Care 4 made several
attempts to schedule virtual parenting time with the parents if they
were unable to attend.
Supervisor 3 reported that visits have not occurred at the parents’
home since parenting time was reinstated following the
kidnapping. She stated Parent B will harp on Youth B about his

the case from DHHS until after the first reporting period, so she

initial removal. She did state she was told during the case transfer
meeting that Parent A would not give Youth A’s medication to the
staff who facilitated the removal. Supervisor 1 stated when she
was assigned to supervise the case, Parent A had sent her
assigned Foster Care Worker a 45-page document about
homeopathic treatment of diabetes. In January of 2022, Parent A
and Parent B were provided with the endocrinologist’s
recommendation regarding insulin treatment, which both parents
resisted. Supervisor 1 stated Youth B’s foster parents have
received diabetic care education and instruction from Youth B’s
endocrinologist and that they have managed his care well.
Supervisor 1 stated that she does not know the specifics of Youth
B’s blood glucose level (BCL) logs but knows that he would spike
high levels following visitation attributed to the parents bringing
sugary snacks and drinks as well as the stress of the visits.
Supervisor 1 reported the court addressed appropriate snacks
with the parents and ordered that all snacks brought to visits
22

follow the endocrinologist’s recommendation, but their solution
was to administer insulin to Youth B to counteract the effects of
sugary snacks.

10/3/2023. Supervisor 2 reported that while Foster Care Worker 2
was assigned the case, Youth B’s foster parents managed his
diabetes well and there were no concerns. He doesn’t recall if
Youth B’s parents participated in Youth B’s medical care.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via video conferencing on
10/3/2023. She reported Foster Care Worker 5 attended an
endocrinologist appointment for Youth B along with the foster
parents and Parent B. She stated she would provide the notes
from that appointment documenting that the foster parents are
providing appropriate treatment and care for Youth B’s diabetes,
conversely, Parent B lacks an understanding of Youth B’s medical
needs. The notes indicate Parent B does not understand the
difference between pump treatment and insulin administration,
which is required for Youth B’s health. Supervisor 3 stated that the
foster parents provide Youth B’s insulin to the agency staff during
parenting times, but they cannot give the insulin to the parents
because they want to give him a dose without first checking his
blood sugar and without there being any signs or symptoms
indicating he needs the insulin.

Worker 4 reached out to the endocrinologist who confirmed the
foster parents were providing proper care for the disease. Foster
Care Worker 4 reported Parent B is stuck on Youth B’s medical
treatment plan prior to removal and does not accept the changes
that have been made over time.

10/3/2023. She stated she attended an endocrinology

has spoken with Youth B’s therapist who indicated Youth A is
23

working on becoming more involved in his diabetic care. She

DOCUMENT REVIEW
• Statement written by Supervisor 3 indicating that the
children were AWOL for 24 hours immediately following
removal (10/4/2021 to 10/5/2021.) Youth B was
hospitalized the following day, 10/6/2021. Youth B’s
diabetes was not properly managed prior to removal and
multiple appointments with the endocrinologist were
missed. A referral was previously made for Youth B to have
receive an insulin pump, but the parents did not follow
through. This has since been done and the foster parent
participated in diabetes education and continue to ensure
that Youth B attends medical appointments as required.
• DHHS 3307 signed by Youth B’s foster parents on
10/5/2022 documenting they were informed of Youth B’s
diabetes.
• 10/6/2021 case contact documenting Youth B was brought
to the emergency room by MDHHS staff where it was
discovered in blood glucose level was high.
• 7/10/2023 endocrinologist assessment documenting Parent
B’s “obvious gaps in knowledge in regard to insulin pump
therapy and blood sugar management” and difficulty
explaining the difference due to Parent B’s multiple
interruptions and not allowing the endocrinologist to speak.
The endocrinologist documented that adjustments will be
made to Youth B’s insulin to better control his BGL now that
he is using an insulin pump but rated his diabetic
management as “fair.”
• Documentation of additional endocrinology appointments
for Youth B on 11/24/2021, 12/31/2021, 1/5/2022,
1/10/2022, 1/13/2022, 2/24/2022 which the foster parents
attended and during which Youth B’s adjustment to the
insulin administration device is monitored.

removal.
The medical documentation since Youth B has been in his foster
home show that he has since been provided an insulin pump and
the foster parents are regularly attending specialist appointments.
24

Adjustments are made to the insulin administration during those
appointments to account for Youth B’s body’s adjustment to the
new device.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
